The Johns Hopkins hoopers turned
the tables on Loyola College for the

night when they triumphed over the

are mathematically out of the race for
honors in the Maryland Collegiate
League, the affair represented more
than the usual attempt of one team to
win a basketball game at the expense
of another. Loyola has been the bugaboo of the Blue Jays since the 193334 hardwood season, and their defeat

The Malloneemen took a 7 point
lead in the first three minutes of play,
and were never as much as tied
throughout the contest. At one stage,
the home team was behind by 1

markers to the 21 by the Loyolans.

rough and tumble element. The Greyhounds forged ahead slightly, to score
23 points to the 19 netted by the
Jays. A noteworthy feature was the
fact that 41 foul shots were taken
during the game.
Hopkins scored first with Harold
Zheutlin tossing the sphere on a pass
from Bing Cross. Melvin added 5
points, to set the total at 7-0. An exchange of long shots, and a shooting

put the counters at 13-12. Hopkins
then went to town, as it were, scoring
easily on quick breaks and excellent
pass work. Melvin's overhead shots

Mt. St. Mary's has definitely
clinched the Maryland Intercollegiate
League championship. But, in the
battle for the various "also-ran" positions, there remains enough competitive spirit to make the rest of the
league contests interesting.
Having successfully met Loyola's
attempt to drop them into the cellar,
the Blue Jay's now have their eyes
peeled on the third place held by
Western Maryland. A victory over
the Green Terrors will move the Hopkins up to this immediate goal, giving
them also a very slight chance of
displacing Washington from their almost certain second-spot.
The Blue Jay quintet will have its
opportunity Thursday evening when
Westminster sends its hopefuls to
Homewood to encounter the Jays for
the second time this season. Earlier in
the year, in a game at Westminster,
the Terrors downed the Hopkins by a
45-40 count. the Jays' desire to avenge
this defeat and the Terrors' hope of
maintaining their league standing
should result in a keenly contested
struggle.
In this second meeting of the two
teams the Homewood club will be favored. The difference between the two
squads in their first engagement was
Stan Benjamin. But Benjamin has
elected to leave school. This leaves
Uvanni as the Terrors' leading threat.
If he is bottled up there should be
nothing but clear sailing for the Jays.

honors in the Maryland Collegiate
League, the affair represented more
than the usual attempt of one team to
win a basketball game at the expense
of another. Loyola has been the bugaboo of the Blue Jays since the 193334 hardwood season, and their defeat

fact that 41 foul shots were taken
during the game.

Mt. St. Mary's has definitely
clinched the Maryland Intercollegiate
League championship. But, in the
battle for the various "also-ran" positions, there remains enough competitive spirit to make the rest of the
league contests interesting.
Having successfully met Loyola's
attempt to drop them into the cellar,
the Blue Jay's now have their eyes
peeled on the third place held by
Western Maryland. A victory over
the Green Terrors will move the Hopkins up to this immediate goal, giving
them also a very slight chance of
displacing Washington from their almost certain second-spot.
The Blue Jay quintet will have its
opportunity Thursday evening when
Westminster sends its hopefuls to
Homewood to encounter the Jays for
the second time this season. Earlier in
the year, in a game at Westminster,
the Terrors downed the Hopkins by a
45-40 count. the Jays' desire to avenge
this defeat and the Terrors' hope of
maintaining their league standing
should result in a keenly contested
struggle.
In this second meeting of the two
teams the Homewood club will be favored. The difference between the two
squads in their first engagement was
Stan Benjamin. But Benjamin has
elected to leave school. This leaves
Uvanni as the Terrors' leading threat.
If he is bottled up there should be
nothing but clear sailing for the Jays.
